newsitem.title: JAMAICA: Bank of Nova Scotia to manage Jamaica's Eagle.
newsitem.headline: Bank of Nova Scotia to manage Jamaica's Eagle.

text.p: Bank of Nova Scotia on Monday took management control of Jamaica's troubled Eagle Group, following the signing of a restructuring deal with the government announced over the weekend.
Eagle chairman Paul Chen-Young sold 80-90 percent of the group to the government for J$1 and formally handed in his resignation.

The group includes a commercial and a merchant bank, a life insurance company, First Equity, a Miami investment bank and two local hotels managed by Holiday Inn. Total group assets stand at US$300 million.
Finance minister Omar Davies has promised that "all savers, depositors and policyholders will be 100 percent protected" and all the groups entities will remain open for business.
Officials say the government's strategy is to return the group to its financial services base and sell off the real estate and hotel ownership.
Eagle ran into trouble when its life company, Crown Eagle, made several bad real estate investments coupled with a massive withdrawal on its equities-linked life polices several years ago.
Crown Eagle turned to the commercial bank for loans, and the overdraft eventually with Jamaica's central bank eventually went to J$6 billion (US$171.4 million).
An estimated J$3 billion (US$85.7 million) will now be provided by government to Eagle to help wipe out the Bank of Jamaica overdraft and provide liquidity support.
Late last month, the government took board control of another life company, Mutual Life, with assets of US$1.6 billion, in return for J$1.5 billion (US$42.8 million) in similar liquidity support.
Officials said over the weekend another three life companies -- Island Life, Dyoll Life and Life of Jamaica -- will split another J$1.7 billion (US$48.5 million) in government support.

All the companies involved have been affected by cash flow problems resulting from a combination of government's tighter monetary policies and the recent slump in the commercial real estate market, in which they had invested heavily.

The authorities have allocated J$6.3 billion (US$180 million) in this first tranche under the restructuring exercise, although more could be made available, according to Davies. The funding will come from a series of short and long-term government bonds to be issued either locally or overseas, he added.
